De los Naranjos s/n 46022 Valencia Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Various strategies to convert CO2 into fuels using light and a photocatalyst are disucssed. In the context of developing renewable fuels for transportation based on Solar light (“Solar Fuels”), products derived from CO2 reduction and particularly methanol and methane appear as appealing renewable feedstocks. Two alternative photocatalytic routes to transform CO2 into methanol and methane which are based either on the use of artificial of solar light to effect the CO2 reduction are presented. It is shown that deep UV activation of CO2 can lead to the selective formation of CO or even to the reduction to methane by hydrogen or water. The latter process can be promoted by the presence of some solids with basic character such as hydrotalcites of alkali-exchanged zeolites. In spite of the high selectivity of these processes, the energy consumption is still too high and efficiency has to be increased. We discuss the limitations of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction arising from the limited choice of semiconductors, the lack of visible response of TiO2, the high reduction potential of CO2 activation, and the dilemma in the use of H2O as sacrificial reducing agent, since H2O can compete favorably for the electrons and produce the preferential generation of H2. The problems arising from the lack of selectivity toward a single product in the CO2 reduction have also been commented. Finally, we present our view on future developments and targets in this field. Keywords Solar Fuels Renewable Energy Photocatalysis Deep UV photolysis 1 Introduction Sunlight is responsible for life on Earth and represents a primary energy resource for the planet [1]. Modern Society is based mainly on the consumption of large amounts of fossil fuels that were originated millions of years ago from plankton and microorganisms that also utilized during their life Sunlight as energy source. In the context of providing potentially viable replacement alternatives to fossil fuels for transportation [2–5], there is much current interest in developing technologies based on solar light for the massive preparation of these chemicals, by exploring any possible route [6–16]. While solar heating [17–22] and photovoltaics [23–40] are viable strategies for some applications, the low energy density of Sunlight and its daily solar cycle make its direct use not viable for transportation, where high-energy powers are required independently of the daytime. In the present article, we will present a short summary of the current state of the art in the preparation of Solar Fuels from CO2 making special emphasis in our view and contribution to this field. 1.1 Solar Fuels Considering the current automotive technologies, one alternative to fossil fuels will be to use as energy vectors some chemicals that accumulate and concentrate the energy of the Sun to be promptly released when required. The concept of “Solar Fuels” has been coined to denote the strategy based on the conversion of Sunlight into chemicals that could be readily employed for transportation when needed [41,42]. Solar Fuels can include some processes based on Natural photosynthesis, such as biomass growth to be subsequently converted into fuels [4,43]. However, considering the constraints of vegetal growth in terms of land and climate requirement, slow growth, weather contingencies, pests, and so on, artificial processes to obtain directly the target chemicals appear also as desirable and possibly advantageous. In this way, the term Solar Fuels refer mainly to the generation of hydrogen from water [15,43–56] and products derived from carbon dioxide such as methanol, methane, carbon monoxide, formic acid, and other chemicals [57–70]. For CO2 photoreduction, the use of molecules and complexes as photocatalysts has been very active [60,71–73], but it seems that applications are more likely to derive from the use of solid photocatalysts. 1.2 Solar Fuels by CO2 reduction While hydrogen technology based on its generation from water and its room temperature oxidation in fuel cells can be the clean, final solution for transportation considering the availability and sustainability of the resource and the lack of pollutants produced, there are currently numerous problems and limitations associated with the use of hydrogen. Among those, the room temperature storage of hydrogen makes this technology not available for immediate application. One possibility worth to be explored would be the implementation of Solar Fuels derived from carbon dioxide and particularly methanol or methane. Methane is currently consumed in massive quantities and if obtained industrially from CO2 and a renewable energy resource, its use will be sustainable and even neutral from the point of view of CO2 footprint, provided that the hydrogen needed is produced from a renewable resource. On the other hand, the use of methanol as fuel could represent a smooth transition between the present technology for transportation and hydrogen technology at much longer term [74]. Methanol can even be viewed as a molecule to store hydrogen that can be released by catalytic reforming and/or as a synthon to produce alkanes, alkenes, and aromatics on zeolite catalysts [75–80]. In addition, methanol itself is an excellent feedstock for fuel cells, allowing the gradual replacement of combustion engines by electrical motors powered by fuel cells based on the use of methanol. Even in this case, the in situ generation of hydrogen by low temperature (about 150°C) catalytic steam reforming of methanol to give hydrogen and carbon dioxide could be considered, for instance, to supply energy for small portable devices or domestic use [81,82]. Therefore, it seems that the efficient and selective reduction of carbon dioxide into methanol or methane could be in principle, a possibility to produce fuels. Herein, we will present recent results on carbon dioxide transformation and our thoughts on possible ways to achieve this target, either on a single step or through an indirect, two-step process. 1.3 Indirect two-step CO2 reduction from solar technologies The reduction of CO2 by H2O to form methanol, methane, or other products is a highly endothermic process (+726 and +802kJmol−1 for methanol and methane, respectively) and requires a considerable amount of energy that will be stored in the chemical compound. This energy will be released during the oxidation of the fuel. There are several ways in which the renewable, primary energy resources as the Sunlight can be used to transform CO2 into fuels. One possibility is a two-step process in which Sunlight is converted by means of photovoltaics into electricity, and then, this electricity is used to perform the catalytic or electrochemical reduction of CO2. Electricity can be obtained also from other primary energy sources. The combination of electricity and the subsequent production of a high-energy fuel is a versatile alternative to the use of batteries and other charge storage devices, with the advantage that the chemical can be an organic compound, while batteries require metals such Li that are available in limited amounts. The obvious advantage of this two-step approach based on the use of artificial light is that the current technology of solar photovoltaic panels is well developed, reaching efficiencies about 40% that are much higher than any other alternative technology. Moreover, any progress in the field of photovoltaics will have a positive impact in the production of Solar Fuels that using this two-step, indirect strategy would be complementary with photovoltaics rather than a competing technology. It can be considered that Solar Fuels based on electricity will be an opportunistic technology taking advantage of the high level of development of Solar panels and photovoltaic technology. The obvious use of electricity from photovoltaics will be the electrochemical reduction of CO2, and this approach offers many opportunities considering that faradaic efficiencies for CO2 conversion, meaning consumed electrons that are used in CO2 reduction, can be as high as 40%. One of the main problems of the electrochemical process is the required over potential as well as the low selectivity toward a single product or a simple mixture of products that could be used without elaborated separation procedures [7,83–85]. In contrast to water reduction that leads to hydrogen as the only product, it should be taken into account that CO2 reduction can lead to a wide range of products going from solids such as carbon, liquids such as methanol and carboxylic acids, and gaseous like methane and CO. For this reason, selectivity can become a key issue in CO2. It has been found, however, that product selectivity and efficiency strongly depends among other parameters on the nature of the electrodes and electrolyte and the applied over potential. Of the various metal electrodes studied, copper electrodes appear to be the preferred ones to favor the reduction of CO2 to methanol and other alcohols, aldehydes, and hydrocarbons [86], although electrode deactivation is commonly observed [86–90]. Copper electrodes also exhibit preferential reduction of CO2 vs. H2O [86]. Considering that water electrolysis is a well-established technology, it can be anticipated that electrochemical CO2 reduction can become a viable strategy, provided that product selectivity and efficiency is further increased. 1.4 Deep UV photolysis of CO2 A much less explored way to use electricity to transform CO2 is the direct photolysis of this compound in the absence of reducing agent to produce CO and O2 (Eq. (1)) using artificial light [91–93]. This two-step strategy would require similarly to the previous case of the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction a highly efficient photochemical processes. CO2 absorbs photons below 200nm in the so-called deep UV region (wavelengths below 200nm requiring pure quartz or metal halides and vacuum), and therefore, CO2 can undergo photochemical reactions if it is irradiated in this spectral range. Quasi monochromatic 185 and 165nm in the deep UV region can be easily obtained using low pressure mercury or deuterium lamps, respectively, that could be powered by electricity produced in photovoltaic panels and used to transform CO2. The point here is to determine the quantum yield and efficiency of this splitting process in terms of energy consumption and to devise procedures to increase the efficiency of the process. One possibility to reduce the energy could be to use deuterium lamps, since mercury lamps are not emitting in the most adequate wavelength for CO2, and the wavelength must determine quantum yields of the process. Then, a possibility to be considered is the coupling of direct photolysis of CO2 and its reduction using deep UV light. Photochemical CO2 reduction is a process that can be carried out in the gas phase using deep UV light to activate directly CO2, but that is also suitable to be performed on the surface of a solid catalyst to enhance the efficiency of the process. Photochemical CO2 reduction requires the presence of hydrogen, water, or other renewable reducing agents as a source of hydrogen. The use of hydrogen is particularly appealing considering that this molecule does not absorb in the deep UV and should not interfere with CO2 photoactivation. We have reported that this approach is viable and that CO2 conversions over 40% can be achieved with very high selectivity toward methane by performing the deep UV photolysis of CO2 in the presence of H2 [96]. Since the seminal report by Fujishima and Honda reporting the photoelectrochemical water splitting with the generation of H2 [97], photocatalytic H2 generation from water has attracted a continued interest [44,48,98–100]. Wide band gap photocatalysts, requiring UV photons, and particularly TiO2 [101,102] appear as the most efficient materials, reaching quantum yields under UV irradiation of about 40%, for H2 generation [103,104]. This is particularly so, when metal NPs (NPs) are deposited on the surface to act as co-catalysts. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction is more difficult and takes place with much lower efficiencies than H2 generation from H2O [57,58,105,106]. The reasons for the lower efficiency and higher difficulty of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction are both thermodynamic and kinetics. Thermodynamics indicate that CO2 reduction requires electrons with higher reduction potential than water reduction leading H2 generation. On the other hand, reaction mechanisms for CO2 reduction must have several steps in which electrons and protons have to be transferred to CO2 consecutively or simultaneously. In contrast, it can be envisioned that just a single electron transfer to H+ is sufficient to trigger H2 formation. Thermodynamics and kinetics explain, therefore, why the photocatalytic CO2 reduction occurs with efficiencies several orders of magnitude lower than the analogous photocatalytic hydrogen generation from water reduction [58,105]. Moreover, it also explains why the presence of H2O can be detrimental for CO2 reduction, since H2 should prevail with respect to the formation of CO2 photoreduction products (see Table 2 and compare the production of H2 and CO2). In natural photosynthesis, green algae and plants are able to reduce CO2 with H2O by the action of Sunlight and convert it into carbohydrates and chemical energy [1]. We are very far from mimicking the complexity of natural photosynthetic centers, reproducing the biochemical machinery to reduce CO2, and the artificial approach is currently based on the use of a single material (“photocatalyst”) to effect the photocatalytic reduction. Starting from a solid photocatalyst and considering their low intrinsic efficiency in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction achieved so far, the current tendencies are aimed at designing the photocatalytic center with adequate substrate adsorption capacity, light harvester, electron, and proton relay units and co-catalysts [49,55,107,108]. Sensitization [109,110] and band gap control [111–113] and modification of the surface polarity [114] can be implemented on a semiconductor to adapt its properties to the exciting light and nature of substrates and products. Most of the studies on photocatalytic CO2 reduction have been focused on the use of TiO2 in its anatase form as photocatalyst [57]. The selection of TiO2 for the initial studies of CO2 photoreduction is not surprising considering the wide availability of this material, its lack of toxicity, its durability and stability and, more important, its high efficiency as photocatalyst under UV irradiation and, in particular, for the photocatalytic water splitting [49,58,102,115,116]. However, it appears that the main conclusion of these preliminary studies is that the choice of TiO2 as photocatalyst for CO2 reduction is unfortunate for reasons that will be outlined below, and there should be an intense search for different and more efficient photocatalysts. The main problem of TiO2 arises from its lack of photoresponse under visible light irradiation. Due to its wide band gap, the light absorption onset for TiO2 starts at wavelengths shorter than 380nm, just in the border between the UV and the visible region. Since solar light only contains about a 4% of the energy in the UV region able to promote photoexcitation of TiO2, a large proportion of Sunlight corresponding to the visible region (about 48% of the total Sunlight energy, the rest being in the IR region) is wasted and not appropriate to excite TiO2. This lack of visible light photoresponse clearly limits the efficiency of TiO2 as photocatalyst, and one of the priorities in photocatalysis has been to expand the photoresponse of TiO2 toward the visible region. This has been achieved in several ways including metal doping [117–119], doping by non-metallic elements with creation of oxygen vacancies [120–122], and more recently by deposition of noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) having surface plasmon band and particularly Au [98–100]. Metal doping replaces a few percents of Ti4+ by other transition metal ion such as Fe3+, Pt4+, or Pd2+ among others. Since the conduction band of TiO2 is essentially constructed by overlapping of Ti 3d orbitals, the presence of other metal introduces empty d orbitals below the conduction band edge, causing the effective band gap reduction. It was found that particularly for reactions carried out in water, doped TiO2 undergo photocorrosion during operation of the photocatalytic cycle, leading to the leaching of the dopant metal and gradual deactivation of the catalyst. Since according to Scheme 1 , the dopant element d orbital is continuously populated and participating in the visible light excitation, the dopant metal undergoes consecutive redox turnovers during operation of the photocatalyst that should lead finally to the migration of the ion outside the lattice (photocorrosion) and deactivation. To solve this problem, it was suggested that non-metallic doping could produce more stable TiO2 photocatalysts. In this approach, there is a density of oxygen vacancies or a percentage of this oxygen is replaced by nonmetal elements such as N, C, or S. Doping of TiO2 can be achieved during the preparation of this semiconductor, for instance using sol–gel procedures starting from Ti(O i Pr)4 in the presence of the corresponding metal or a source of the nonmetal element or starting from TiO2 by post-synthetic procedures using solid-phase doping. The main problem of both approaches is the difficulty in reproducing exactly the photocatalytic activity of the material due variations in the dopant loading and its location. For instance, there is a need of thermal annealing at temperatures above 400°C in the sol–gel synthesis that can effect the migration of the dopant during formation of the anatase crystal phase. The exact experimental conditions of the annealing in terms of temperature program, time, humidity, and even the thickness of the calcinations bed can lead to different results. Similar problems of reproducibility are encountered in the solid-phase reactions. Deposition of Au NPs on P25 TiO2 (Au/TiO2) is advantageous for the preparation of visible light photocatalyst considering the easy of sample reproducibility from one laboratory to another. Au/TiO2 is widely used in heterogeneous catalysis to promote the low temperature CO oxidation, selective nitro group hydrogenation, as well as many other reactions. The interest and ample use of Au/TiO2 is revealed by the fact that the World Gold Council has been distributing commercial Au/TiO2 (1wt.% Au loading, 5nm average particle size) as a reference catalyst to contrast the activity from different labs. In the case of Au/TiO2, its visible light photocatalytic activity is proposed to derive from photoexcitation at the characteristic absorption of Au, expanding from 450 till 700nm and peaking at 560nm. The main advantages of using Au NPs are the low loadings needed to achieve the maximum photocatalytic activity (typically below 1wt.%), the stability of Au NPs against photocorrosion due to the noble character of Au metal, and their visible light absorption. Excitation of the Au NPs will inject hot electrons into the conduction band of TiO2, similarly to conventional photosensitization by organic dyes (Scheme 1). Electron injection from Au NPs to TiO2 crossing the interfacial surface is a key elementary step that typically controls the efficiency of the overall photocatalytic process. This should lead to a state of charge separation in which electrons would be located on the TiO2 conduction band and positive holes on the Au NPs. According to this rationalization, the reduction potential of electrons in Au/TiO2 should be the same as in TiO2, but the oxidation potential of the positive holes should be considerably lower than those located on TiO2, and this could be a limitation to effect water oxidation. In addition, Au NPs can also act as catalytic sites, a role that is being increasingly recognized in photocatalysis in order to develop efficient systems [8,123]. Also, it can be that, in the presence of oxygen due to contamination from the atmosphere, generation from water or even from the metal oxide lattice, Au NPs catalyze the generation of peroxides, and this process promoted by Au NPs being detrimental for the photocatalytic reduction, since it would represent the quenching of electrons by oxygen. In this way, an efficient photocatalyst not only should perform light absorption and charge separation with high quantum yields and long lifetime, but also should have appropriate catalytic sites in where chemical redox processes leading to the desired products should take place with low activation barriers. In fact, Au/TiO2 was tested as photocatalyst for water splitting under UV light irradiation in the early 1980s by Haruta and found to exhibit similar but lower productivity than an analogous Pt/TiO2. Pt/TiO2, however, does not exhibit visible light photocatalytic activity. Compared to Au/TiO2, other metal NPs exhibiting also surface plasmon band and, therefore, can be potential excited with visible light such as Ag NPs are not so stable and undergo photocorrosion and photoelectrolysis during the operation of the photocatalytic reaction, thus limiting the applicability of the material. However, none of these modified titania photocatalysts having response in the visible region have been reported yet to be efficient to promote photocatalytic CO2 reduction with decent yields. This fact is not totally unexpected considering that the efficiency of TiO2 under UV for CO2 reduction is much lower than that of water reduction which also takes place (though unsatisfactorily) under visible light irradiation [99,100]. One of the reasons for this low efficiency associated with the use of TiO2 could be the low reduction potential of electrons in its conduction band (≈−0.1V) that is much lower than the theoretical thermodynamics requirements for one electron reduction of CO2 (Eq. (2)). In this regard, it would be more convenient to engineer the energy of the conduction and valence to the adequate values to reduce CO2, and oxidize water plus the corresponding over potentials. Band gap engineering of TiO2 crystals or any other semiconductor is a strategy that should be supported by theoretical calculations of the density of states and their corresponding energies and reaction mechanisms. It is remarkable the paucity of theoretical studies dealing with this important issue in photocatalysis, and in our opinion, considerably more emphasis should be made in this area in the next years. The potential required to reduce CO2 can be considerably reduced if simultaneously to the transfer of the electron, a proton stabilizing the developing CO 2 - radical anion is also transferred (Eq. (3)). In fact, the thermodynamic potential of CO2 reduction decreases progressively even further if several electrons and protons could be simultaneously transferred in pairs to CO2 (Eqs. (4)–(7)). In this sense, Eq. (7) is thermodynamically considerably much less endergonic than Eq. (2). Such processes in which all protons and electrons needed to form CH4 and H2O are transferred seem kinetically unfeasible to occur in a single step. This suggests that the ideal photocatalyst should have photocatalytic centers in which sites transferring electrons are close enough to other sites acting as acids and transferring at least one proton according to Eqs. (3)–(7). It has also to be considered that strong adsorption of CO2 on the photocatalyst surface due to the presence of basic sites and microporosity can play a favorable role in the photocatalytic process by increasing the concentration of this substrate near the reactive sites and by decreasing the activation energy of the process. The use of microporous solids that could exhibit increased CO2 adsorption will introduce diffusion through the pores as an additional issue. The hydrocarbon production rate of this N-doped TiO2 nanotube array with solar light was 31.9nmolcm−2 h−1 that was estimated based on the weight of the array as 20 times higher than values previously reported for TiO2 nanoparticles under UV light irradiation [125]. 1.6 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction by H2O Another problem associated with the photocatalytic CO2 reduction in aqueous solutions is that the photocatalytic reduction of water to hydrogen, a process requiring in principle lower energy, can take place simultaneously competing with CO2 reduction. CO2 can only undergo reduction and requires the presence of a co-reagent that should undergo simultaneously oxidation. As already commented, the most convenient reduction reagent is water that upon oxidation to molecular dioxygen should provide the hydrogen atoms that will incorporate CO2. However, in contrast to CO2, H2O can undergo oxidation to O2 by trapping positive holes in the semiconductor valence band, but also reduction to H2 by electrons in the conduction band of the semiconductor. The term “overall” water splitting refers to the situation in which water is simultaneously oxidized to oxygen and reduced to hydrogen in the photocatalytic process without the need of any additional reagent. This dual behavior of H2O complicates CO2 reduction, since H2O added to provide hydrogen atoms to CO2 can be considered as a competing reagent for reduction. In fact, under the conditions of photocatalytic CO2 reduction, generation of molecular hydrogen from water should be the prevalent process from the thermodynamic point of view. For this reason, it is very common that under conditions for the photocatalytic CO2 reduction, formation of H2 appears as the prevalent product. It is very likely that any industrial process for CO2 reduction has to contemplate also the formation and use of large amounts of H2 in the process. We have already commented this simultaneous generation of H2 in the deep UV photocatalytic activation of CO2 in the presence of H2O when the results of Table 2 were discussed. However, the occurrence of competitive CO2 reduction and H2 formation can mislead about the activity of certain photocatalysts in which CO2 reduction has been tested in water and happen to produce considerable amounts of H2, without photoreduction of CO2. It could happen that under other conditions, particularly in the gas phase with controlled proportion of water or in the presence of an alternative reductant agent, the photocatalytic activity of this material for CO2 reduction is much higher than previously observed. Therefore, some photocatalysts could be worth to be evaluated under conditions in which water reduction is disfavored. From the point of view of testing photocatalytic activity of semiconductors, it could be worth using other compounds such alcohols and amines. These compounds are highly efficient sacrificial electron donors trapping holes in the semiconductor and undergoing oxidation. But because these compounds are more difficult to be reduced than water, it can be expected that they will not compete with CO2 in the trapping of the electrons in the conduction band. 1.7 Gas phase vs. liquid phase photocatalysis Another aspect that has to be considered with regard to the experimental procedure to perform the photocatalytic CO2 reduction derives from the low solubility of CO2 in water at ambient temperature, atmospheric pressure, and acid pH values (about 30mmolL−1) [126]. In order to increase water solubility, basic pH values are necessary, but this converts CO2 into CO 3 2 - or HCO 3 - that are more stable and more difficult to reduce than CO2 itself. As we have already been commenting, the CO2 reduction potential decreases in the presence of H+, and these acid conditions are in contradiction with the solubility in water. Even more, CO 3 2 - are good hole quenchers and undergo easy oxidation to oxygen. The overall cycle of CO2 dissolution in aqueous base (Eq. (9)) and subsequent photocatalytic oxidation of CO 3 2 - (Eq. (11)) consists really in the oxidation of hydroxide ions to oxygen (Eq. (13)) rather than in reduction of CO2 and raises concerns about the advantages of using aqueous base to effect CO2 reduction. Obviously, operation of Eqs. (9) and (12) will consume the base that should be continuously added to the system, limiting severely the feasibility of the process. (9) CO 2 + OH - → HCO 3 - (10) HCO 3 - + OH - → CO 3 (11) CO 3 + h + → CO 3 - (12) 2 CO 3 - → 2 CO 2 + O 2 (13) 2 OH - → O 2 Formation of water-soluble products from CO2 reduction and ways to recover them are also important problems when using H2O as solvent that would limit the applicability of the process. On the one hand, the products formed such as methanol are highly reactive in the conditions of the photocatalytic process and will decompose, reaching a stationary low concentration. On the other hand, they can be considered as poisons, stopping the photocatalytic reduction. Continuous flow operation could alleviate product decomposition and catalyst deactivation, provided that conversion values are sufficiently increased. However, recovery of CO2 reduction products in highly diluted aqueous solutions would still represent an important challenge. For these reasons, it could be of interest to test other solvents or to perform the reduction in the gas phase in the presence of limited amounts of water or other reducing agents. In this case, the photocatalyst must have enough CO2 adsorption capacity to ensure the presence of a sufficiently high amount of CO2 on its surface to promote the photocatalytic reduction efficiently. Provision of H+ to the medium must also be considered according to Eqs. (3)–(7), so the reduction potential decreases to lower values. 1.8 Selectivity in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction However, gas-phase photoreduction may not be such as optimal reaction conditions as considered at first sight if photocatalytic reduction is not selective toward a gas-phase product. Another distinctive feature of photocatalytic CO2 reduction with respect to the photocatalytic hydrogen generation from water is the wide range of products that can be formed from CO2, including the most commonly desirable products methanol and methane, but also oxalic and formic acids, carbon monoxide, formaldehyde, and even elemental carbon. Thus, while in the photocatalytic water splitting, the only products formed are H2 and O2, photocatalytic CO2 reduction is far more complex and can lead to a wide range of products. On the one hand, this lack of selectivity can reduce the interest of the photocatalysis and complicate the process of the resulting mixture, but on the other hand, some of the products can act as poisons of the photocatalyst, quenchers of the charge separate state or even undergo degradation to give back CO2. Generally, photocatalytic CO2 reduction is not selective, and several products are simultaneously formed. Typically, these products are accompanied by even higher percentages of hydrogen, as we have already explained. At the present, there is a lack of understanding on the factors that control the product distribution. Moreover, there is a lack of conceptual framework of how to modify the photocatalyst to direct the reduction toward the formation of a single product. Also, in the case of product distribution, computational studies of the reaction pathways and the factors controlling the formation of certain products are necessary to provide a conceptual framework in the preparation and modification of the photocatalysts and the understanding of the architecture of the sites that would lead to methanol or methane formation. The problem arises from the considerable differences in the physical and chemical properties of the potential products derived from CO2 that, on the one hand, complicates the analysis of the product distribution and the recovery of the non-gaseous products, but, on the other can deposit on the photocatalyst surface causing apparent deactivation. Mass balances of consumed CO2 have to be always performed to firmly ascertain that deposition on the solid phase is not taking place. Also, photocatalytic studies have to be surveyed to determine if the possibility of formation of products such as carbonates, elemental carbon, oxalic acid, and formic acid has been considered, and analytical techniques besides GC have been employed. 2 Conclusions In the above sections, we have tried to convey the interest of developing CO2 reduction by photochemical means in the context of renewable Solar Fuels for transportation. This process combines basic science with the advancement of fundamental knowledge. From the chemical point of view, CO2 reduction constitutes an enormous challenge due to the need to develop photocatalysts with sites fulfilling the thermodynamic and kinetic requirements such as high reduction potential of photogenerated electrons and simultaneous transfer of electrons and protons. We have shown that the use of H2O as reducing agent raises a dilemma on how to reduce efficiently CO2 without performing exclusive or predominantly the reduction of H2O. We have emphasized that the field is just in its infancy and is still characterized by the poor efficiency of the processes, even under UV or deep UV irradiation. We have presented new data indicating that strategies based on artificial light should not be dismissed and can have some competitive advantages with respect to the direct sunlight photocatalytic process. The need of developing conceptual frameworks to lead the synthesis of new photocatalysts has been highlighted throughout the article. coredata.dc:description: In the context of developing renewable fuels for transportation based on Solar light (“Solar Fuels”), products derived from CO2 reduction and particularly methanol and methane appear as appealing renewable feedstocks. Two alternative photocatalytic routes to transform CO2 into methanol and methane which are based either on the use of artificial of solar light to effect the CO2 reduction are presented. It is shown that deep UV activation of CO2 can lead to the selective formation of CO or even to the reduction to methane by hydrogen or water. The latter process can be promoted by the presence of some solids with basic character such as hydrotalcites of alkali-exchanged zeolites. In spite of the high selectivity of these processes, the energy consumption is still too high and efficiency has to be increased. We discuss the limitations of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction arising from the limited choice of semiconductors, the lack of visible response of TiO2, the high reduction potential of CO2 activation, and the dilemma in the use of H2O as sacrificial reducing agent, since H2O can compete favorably for the electrons and produce the preferential generation of H2. The problems arising from the lack of selectivity toward a single product in the CO2 reduction have also been commented. Finally, we present our view on future developments and targets in this field.
